questions.text: Calculate Amplitude in case of near vision of 20 cm and far point of infinity. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5D

 

Explanation:


To calculate the amplitude of accommodation, we use the formula:

 

Amplitude = 1/Near Point (in meters)

 

Calculation steps:

 

  1. Convert 20 cm to meters: 20 cm = 0.2 meters
  2. Apply the formula: 1/0.2 = 5 diopters

 

When the far point is at infinity (no refractive error), the amplitude is simply calculated by taking the inverse of the near point distance in meters.

 

Educational Objective: 


The amplitude of accommodation using the formula: 1/Near Point (in meters), with the far point at infinity resulting in a direct inverse calculation of the near point distance.

choices.text: Chronic HTN with superimposed preeclampsia

questions.text: A G2P1 at 17 weeks presented to the OPD with a BP of 148/90 mmHg. Six hours later, her BP is 142/90 mmHg. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic HTN

 

In pregnancy, the timing of hypertension onset is critical in determining the diagnosis. Chronic hypertension is defined as high blood pressure that is present before pregnancy or that is diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation. This patient's blood pressure readings of 148/90 mmHg and 142/90 mmHg at 17 weeks of gestation indicate hypertension occurring before the 20-week threshold, fitting the definition of chronic hypertension.

 

To confirm chronic hypertension, if the patient's blood pressure remains elevated 12 weeks postpartum, the diagnosis is solidified.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preeclampsia: This is incorrect because preeclampsia is characterized by hypertension that develops after 20 weeks of gestation and is accompanied by proteinuria. This patient's hypertension was noted before 20 weeks and there is no mention of proteinuria.

 

Option B. Gestational HTN: This option is incorrect as gestational hypertension also develops after 20 weeks of gestation. This patient's hypertension was detected at 17 weeks, making this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option D. Chronic HTN with superimposed preeclampsia: This is incorrect because superimposed preeclampsia would require evidence of new-onset proteinuria or worsening hypertension after 20 weeks of gestation in a patient with pre-existing chronic hypertension. There is no mention of proteinuria in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypertension diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation in a pregnant woman is most likely chronic hypertension.

choices.text: Vitamin B12 and Folic acid deficiency

questions.text: Which type of anemia is associated with an elevated Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV) and a normal Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12 and Folic acid deficiency

 

Vitamin B12 and folate deficiencies are classic causes of macrocytic anemia with elevated MCV (typically >100 fL) and normal MCHC. These deficiencies impair DNA synthesis while RNA and protein synthesis continue, resulting in nuclear-cytoplasmic asynchrony and the production of larger red blood cells. The peripheral blood smear shows macrocytes that are often oval-shaped (macro-ovalocytes).

 

Evidences:            

 

  • Macrocytic anemias show MCV values >100 fL
  • Polychromasia describes red cells that are slightly larger than normal with a grayish-blue color on Wright-Giemsa stain
  • B12 deficiency affects myelination of the central nervous system while folate deficiency primarily affects rapidly dividing cells

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Sideroblastic anemia: Characterized by ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow and typically presents with microcytosis or normocytosis, not macrocytosis.
  • Option C. Beta thalassemia: Associated with microcytosis (low MCV), hypochromia, and target cells. The MCHC is typically decreased.
  • Option D. Iron deficiency anemia: Presents with microcytosis (MCV <80 fL) and hypochromia (low MCHC). The peripheral blood smear shows small, pale red cells with increased central pallor.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vitamin B12 and folate deficiencies impair DNA synthesis leading to megaloblastic changes with macrocytosis (elevated MCV) but normal MCHC, distinguishing them from other nutritional anemias.

questions.text: Composition of lactulose: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactose + Fructose

 

Lactulose is a synthetic disaccharide composed of the monosaccharides galactose and fructose. The name "lactulose" suggests its relation to lactose, which is composed of glucose and galactose. However, the "ulose" suffix indicates the presence of a ketone group, identifying fructose as the other component.

 

Lactulose is particularly significant in medicine for its role in treating constipation and hepatic encephalopathy. It is not digested in the small intestine and in large intestine its fermented by intestinal bacteria, producing an acidic pH. This helps in trapping ammonia in the gut by converting it to ammonium ions, which are not reabsorbed, thus aiding in the management of hepatic encephalopathy. Additionally, lactulose creates an osmotic gradient that softens stool, making it effective for treating constipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose + Galactose: This option describes the composition of lactose, not lactulose. Lactose is a naturally occurring disaccharide found in milk and dairy products.

 

Option B. Glucose + Fructose: This combination forms sucrose, commonly known as table sugar, and is not related to lactulose.

 

Option D. Fructose + Ribulose: This combination does not form any common disaccharide relevant to this context, making it incorrect for lactulose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sucrose = Glucose + Fructose
  • Trehalose = Glucose + Glucose
  • Maltose = Glucose + Glucose
  • Lactose = Glucose + Galactose
  • Lactulose = Galactose + Fructose

questions.text: A patient presents with a firm, tender, slow-growing mass below the ear as shown in the image below. What could be the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parotid abscess

 

  • The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of a parotid abscess.
  • It is suppuration of the parotid space. Deep cervical fascia splits into two layers, superficial and deep, to enclose the parotid gland and its associated structures. Parotid space lies deep to its superficial layer.
  • Dehydration, particularly in postsurgical cases and debilitated patients, with stasis of salivary flow is the predisposing cause.
  • Most common organism- Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Presents with unilateral swelling associated with redness, induration, and tenderness over the parotid gland and angle of the mandible. Dehydration and fever are also present.
  • Investigations -
    • Diagnosis is by ultrasonography or a CT scan – to know extent of abscess
    • Aspiration of abscess for culture and sensitivity to isolate causative organism
  • Treatment -
    • Surgical drainage of the abscess is done via a preauricular incision along with IV antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bezold abscess: is a complication of mastoiditis which presents as swelling in upper part of neck when pus breaks inferiorly, through the tip of the mastoid

 

Option C. Upper cervical lymphadenopathy: occurs in the neck region following infection in the area drained by these structures.

 

Option D. Osteoma of the mandible: characterized by a benign, slow-growing tumor on the mandible, which is usually painless and asymptomatic, not presenting with tenderness and acute symptoms like an abscess.

 

Educational Objective:


Diagnosing and treating a parotid abscess promptly is crucial to prevent further complications such as the spread of infection. The characteristic presentation of swelling, tenderness, and systemic signs in a specific location aids in differential diagnosis from other potential conditions affecting the neck and jaw area.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 297

questions.text: A hair shaft with arthroconidia is seen in the image below. Identify the fungi associated with it? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microsporum

 

The image shows a hair shaft containing arthroconidia, which are fungal spores that develop within or on the surface of the hair. The key points to consider are:

 

  • Endothrix and Ectothrix: Endothrix refers to fungal infections where the spores (arthroconidia) are found inside the hair shaft, while ectothrix refers to infections where spores are found on the outside of the hair shaft.
  • Microsporum: Although typically associated with ectothrix infections, in this scenario, it is the most appropriate answer given that the other options are less likely to produce this specific pattern.

 

Despite Microsporum generally being linked to ectothrix infections, it remains the best answer in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichosporon: Incorrect because it is associated with white piedra and does not form arthroconidia within the hair shaft.

 

Option C. Candida: Incorrect because Candida does not cause infections within the hair shaft; it is primarily involved in mucosal and cutaneous infections.

 

Option D. Epidermophyton: Incorrect because this fungus does not infect hair; it is more commonly associated with skin and nail infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microsporum can be associated with fungal infections of the hair shaft, particularly in cases where arthroconidia are observed. Even though it is more commonly linked with ectothrix infections, it is the best option among the given choices for this scenario

choices.text: Porta hepatis and inferior vena cava
Right and left lobe of liver

questions.text: The cholecysto-vena caval line is an anatomical landmark that connects which of the following structures? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gallbladder and inferior vena cava

 

  • The cholecysto-vena caval line (Cantlie line) considered as true mid line of liver.
  • The Cantlie line is a fictitious line that divides the liver into two parts.
  • It contains the middle hepatic vein and extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the groove for inferior vena cava (IC).

 

 

Anatomy on visceral surface of the liver with division into right and left lobes by the plane of Rex-Cantlie line.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Porta Hepatis and Inferior Vena Cava: The porta hepatis, often called the "hilum of the liver," is a deep fissure on the inferior surface of the liver where several key structures, including the portal vein, common hepatic duct, and hepatic artery, enter or leave the liver. Though the porta hepatis is an essential landmark in liver anatomy and surgery, it's not associated with the cholecysto-vena caval line.

 

Option C. Caudate Lobe and Quadrangular Lobe: There isn't a distinct "quadrangular lobe" in the human liver. The liver has main lobes named right, left, caudate, and quadrate lobes. The caudate and quadrate lobes are smaller lobes situated on the liver's inferior surface. While they have importance in liver anatomy, they don't define the cholecysto-vena caval line.

 

Option D. Right and Left Lobe of Liver: On the Diaphragamatic surface Tthe human liver is typically divided into a larger right lobe and a smaller left lobe by the falciform ligament (anteriorly). The cholecysto-vena caval line helps delineate the boundary between the right and left lobes when viewed posteriorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cholecysto-vena caval line is an imaginary line drawn from the fundus of the gallbladder to the point where the inferior vena cava (IVC) pierces the diaphragm. It roughly demarcates the boundary between the right and left lobes of the liver, especially when viewed from behind (posterior view).

questions.text: A person develops headache and breathlessness on a trekking expedition following rapid ascent to over 3000 metres above the sea level. Which of the following is not used in treatment of the above condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. IV digoxin

 

The condition described in the scenario is likely High-Altitude Headache (HAH) and High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE), which can occur due to rapid ascent to high altitudes.

 

Digoxin is a medication primarily used for the treatment of heart conditions, such as heart failure and certain irregular heart rhythms like atrial fibrillation therefore, digoxin is not used for the above condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immediate Descent: This is the most effective treatment for HAPE and other altitude sickness symptoms. Descending to lower altitudes where the air pressure is higher can alleviate symptoms by increasing the available oxygen.

 

Option C. Administration of Oxygen: Providing supplemental oxygen can help alleviate the symptoms of hypoxia experienced at high altitudes, directly addressing the oxygen deficit caused by the thin air.

 

Option D. Tablet Acetazolamide: Acetazolamide is a diuretic that helps prevent and reduce the symptoms of altitude sickness. It works by acidifying the blood, which stimulates breathing, increasing oxygen intake and helping the body adjust to changes in altitude.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barometric pressure, partial pressure of oxygen and common effects at different altitudes

 

 

Treatment

 

  1. Oxygen supplementation
  2. Move to a lower altitude
  3. Acetazolamide – stimulates respiration and reduced intracranial pressure
  4. Portable hyperbaric bags (E.g., Gamow bag) simulate descent to a lower altitude.

questions.text: A mother comes to the hospital with her newborn baby. On examination, surfactants are not adequately found and collapse of alveoli was seen. What will be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory distress syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) is a condition commonly seen in premature infants where the lungs are not fully developed, leading to a deficiency in surfactant. Surfactant is crucial for reducing surface tension within the alveoli, allowing them to remain open and facilitating proper gas exchange. Without adequate surfactant, the alveoli collapse, leading to impaired gas exchange and difficulty breathing, which is the hallmark of RDS. In this case, the mother's newborn shows signs of inadequate surfactant and alveolar collapse, making RDS the most probable diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchial asthma: This condition involves chronic inflammation of the airways, typically seen in older children and adults, not newborns. It presents with symptoms such as wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath but is not associated with surfactant deficiency or alveolar collapse.

 

Option C. Pneumonia: This is an infection of the lungs that can cause fever, cough, and difficulty breathing. While it can affect newborns, it does not involve surfactant deficiency or the collapse of alveoli.

 

Option D. Pleural effusion: This condition involves the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space around the lungs. It can cause breathing difficulties but is not related to surfactant deficiency or alveolar collapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory distress syndrome in newborns is primarily due to a lack of surfactant, leading to alveolar collapse and breathing difficulties.

questions.text: Which of the following acute phase reactants is known to induce rouleaux formation in erythrocytes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Fibrinogen

 

Explanation: 

 

Fibrinogen is an acute phase reactant that binds to red blood cells and causes them to form stacks called rouleaux. This property of fibrinogen is the basis for measuring the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), which is a simple test for detecting inflammatory responses. During inflammation, fibrinogen levels increase in the blood, enhancing rouleaux formation and consequently increasing the ESR. This occurs because the stacked red cells sediment more rapidly at unit gravity than individual red cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C-reactive protein (CRP) - While CRP is an important acute phase protein that can bind to microbial cell walls and act as an opsonin, it does not directly cause rouleaux formation. CRP is involved in complement activation and enhancing phagocytosis.

 

Option C. Serum Amyloid Associated (SAA) protein - SAA is another acute phase protein produced during inflammation, but it primarily binds to chromatin and microbial cell walls. It doesn't induce rouleaux formation. Prolonged production of SAA can lead to secondary amyloidosis.

 

Option D. IL-1 - This is a cytokine rather than an acute phase reactant. IL-1 is produced by activated macrophages and stimulates the liver to produce acute phase proteins, but it doesn't directly cause rouleaux formation.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fibrinogen is the acute phase reactant responsible for rouleaux formation in erythrocytes, which is the physiological basis for the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) test used to detect inflammatory conditions.

questions.text: A suspect of sexual assault of 18 years of age claims to be of 16 years. X-rays of which area can confirm the correct age of the suspect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D)  Knee and wrist

 

To determine the accurate age of a person based on bone ossification, certain joints are examined through X-rays. The ossification of specific bones indicates different age groups. The wrist and knee typically ossify by the age of 18, while other joints, such as the elbow, ossify by the age of 16. In this case, the suspect is claiming to be 16 years old, but if X-rays of both the knee and wrist show full ossification, this would confirm that the suspect is actually 18 years old. This is because these areas would not be fully ossified at 16 but would be ossified at 18, matching the age of the suspect.

 

For 18 years of age:

 

 

For 16 years of age:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elbow and hip: The elbow and hip ossify by the age of 16. If these joints were ossified, it would support the suspect's claim of being 16 years old, which would not be useful in confirming that they are 18.

 

Option B. Elbow and wrist: The elbow ossifies at 16, but the wrist ossifies at 18. This combination would not be conclusive for determining that the suspect is 18 years old.

 

Option C. Knee and elbow: The elbow ossifies at 16, while the knee ossifies at 18. Similar to option B, this combination would be ambiguous and not definitive for confirming that the suspect is 18.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The ossification of the wrist and knee is a reliable indicator of whether an individual is 18 years old, as both these areas ossify by that age.

questions.text: A patient had a renal tumor and brain tumor with multiple members in the family being affected in previous generations. Which of the following is the likely gene involved in this individual? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) VHL gene

 

The clinical presentation of renal tumors, brain tumors, and a strong family history of similar tumors suggests Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome.

 

VHL syndrome is a genetic condition caused by mutations in the VHL gene located on chromosome 3.

 

It is characterized by the development of various types of tumors, including clear cell renal cell carcinoma, hemangioblastomas of the central nervous system (particularly in the cerebellum), and pheochromocytomas.

 

Patients with VHL syndrome are at increased risk for these tumors, and the condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, explaining the presence of multiple affected family members.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RET gene: The RET gene is associated with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2 (MEN2), which primarily involves medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytomas, and parathyroid adenomas. It is not linked with renal or brain tumors.

 

Option B. TSC gene: The TSC gene is related to Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, which is associated with benign tumors in multiple organs, including the brain, skin, heart, and kidneys. However, it is characterized by epilepsy, skin manifestations, and cardiac tumors, which are not the main features presented in this question.

 

Option D. Li-Fraumeni syndrome: Li-Fraumeni syndrome is caused by mutations in the TP53 gene and is characterized by a broad spectrum of cancers, including soft tissue sarcomas, osteosarcomas, brain tumors, breast cancer, and leukemias. However, it does not specifically target the combination of brain and renal tumors seen in VHL syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is associated with renal cell carcinoma, cerebellar hemangioblastomas, and pheochromocytomas, and it is caused by mutations in the VHL gene on chromosome 3.

choices.text: It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases
It shows Ad type of curve

questions.text: A patient has otitis media with effusion. Which of the following is wrong?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It shows Ad type of curve

 

Otitis media with effusion (OME) is a condition characterized by the presence of fluid in the middle ear without signs or symptoms of acute ear infection. The incorrect statement regarding it is, It shows Ad type of curve. This statement is incorrect. OME typically shows a B type of tympanogram curve. A B type curve indicates the presence of middle ear fluid. An Ad type curve is associated with ossicular discontinuity, which is not related to OME.

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is bilateral: Can be true but not mandatory; OME can be unilateral or bilateral.

 

Option B. It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases: True, as the condition often resolves with the resolution of the underlying URTI.

 

Option C. It is associated with cold: True, as URTI and colds can lead to Eustachian tube dysfunction and subsequent fluid accumulation in the middle ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otitis media with effusion shows a B type of tympanogram curve, not an Ad type curve.

questions.text: An infant is brought to OPD with hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia. Neuroimaging with CT reveals periventricular calcifications. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital cytomegalovirus infection

 

Congenital CMV is reported to be the commonest congenital infection. The overall transmission rate with primary infection is 30% and 10% of all babies infected are symptomatic. Congenital infection can affect all organ systems. Periventricular calcification is characteristic. The diagnosis of congenital CMV is confirmed by a positive IgM in the first two weeks of life.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital rubella syndrome: Rubella causes most severe form of intra uterine infection. If infection sets within 11 weeks POG – 90% defects, if 11-12 weeks – 33% defects chances. More the weeks pass, less is the frequency of having CRS infections. Presentation is similar like measles rash but rash appears on day 1 & lasts for 3 days (3 days measles). Triad – congenital heart disease (MC – PDA; Least Common – ASD), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL).

 

Option B. Congenital herpes simplex virus infection: The transmission of HSV to babies usually occurs during delivery in mothers who develop primary genital herpes at that time. Infected babies may be asymptomatic or have fulminant disease. Presents with vesicular eruption on to skin, eyes and mouth. CNS disease that presents as meningitis with seizures and altered sensorium. Diagnosis is by Tzanck smear of the skin lesions, culture or PCR of lesions or cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Option C. Congenital toxoplasmosis: Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs due to maternal primary infection, which is generally subclinical may lead to fetal infection and disease. The transmissibility increases but the risk of fetal disease decreases with advancing pregnancy. It presents with a triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Periventricular calcifications on neuroimaging, along with hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia, are characteristic of congenital cytomegalovirus infection.

questions.text: Following is the x-ray of an 18-year-old boy who complains of fever, pain in the lower limb, local rise of temperature, and tenderness in the area shown. On investigation, he has increased ESR. What can be the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ewing's sarcoma

 

  • This case presents a teenager (18-year-old) with symptoms of fever, pain, local rise in temperature, and tenderness in the lower limb, along with increased ESR are suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma.
  • Radiological features:
    • The first image shows a layered periosteal reaction (onion-skin appearance), which is characteristic of Ewing's sarcoma.
    • The second and third images show a permeative pattern of bone destruction with a soft tissue mass, another hallmark of Ewing's sarcoma.
  • Ewing's sarcoma typically affects children and adolescents (common in ages 10–20).
  • Symptoms include localized pain, swelling, fever, and elevated ESR, often mimicking infection like osteomyelitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Germ cell tumor: Germ cell tumors typically arise in the reproductive organs (testes or ovaries) or occasionally outside these locations (extragonadal). It is not typically a primary bone tumor and doesn't fit the radiographic pattern.

 

Option B. Osteomyelitis: Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone and can cause fever, pain, and elevated ESR, mimicking the symptoms of this case. However, osteomyelitis is more likely to show a solid periosteal reaction or sequestra on x-ray. Osteomyelitis may look similar clinically but rarely shows onion-skin periosteal reaction.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is another malignant bone tumor that commonly presents with a sunburst appearance and Codman’s triangle on x-ray. However, osteosarcoma typically arises in the metaphysis (the wide part at the ends of bones), particularly in the distal femur or proximal tibia, rather than the diaphysis. It usually presents with pain and swelling but not systemic signs like fever and high ESR to this extent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ewing’s sarcoma typically presents in the diaphysis of long bones in children and adolescents, with a onion skin periosteal reaction seen on x-ray.

choices.text: Superficial from border with normal tissue

questions.text: A patient presents with a growth on the lip as shown. How is the biopsy taken? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superficial from border with normal tissue

 

In cases of ulcerative growths, such as squamous cell carcinoma of the lip, the biopsy is typically taken from the border of the ulcer where the tissue is actively proliferating. This method is known as a wedge or edge biopsy, where a small section from the edge of the ulcer and adjacent normal tissue is removed. This approach is preferred because the most diagnostically significant tissue lies at the proliferating margins of the ulcer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incisional: An incisional biopsy involves removing a piece of tissue from the core of the lesion. This technique is typically used for solid masses, such as breast lumps, where a core sample is required to assess the deeper tissue architecture. It is not appropriate for ulcerative lesions where the proliferative activity is at the edges.

 

Option B. Excisional: An excisional biopsy involves removing the entire lesion along with some surrounding normal tissue. While this is useful for small lesions where complete removal is feasible, it is not the standard initial approach for large or ulcerated lesions like those seen in aggressive lip cancers.

 

Option D. Deep biopsy: A deep biopsy targets deeper tissue layers, which may be necessary for certain internal masses but is not suitable for superficial ulcerative lesions like lip growths, where the pathology is best captured at the surface and edges.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For ulcerative lesions, particularly squamous cell carcinomas, a biopsy should be taken from the border or edge of the lesion, including some normal tissue, as this area contains the most diagnostically relevant proliferating cells.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with symptoms of bone pain, anemia, hypercalcemia, and renal impairment. A bone marrow biopsy confirms the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The patient is started on a treatment regimen. Which of the following treatments is most likely associated with the reactivation of herpes zoster? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bortezomib

 

Bortezomib is a proteasome inhibitor that is commonly used in the treatment of multiple myeloma. It works by inhibiting the proteasome, which is essential for protein degradation in cells, leading to the accumulation of proteins that induce cell death, particularly in cancer cells. However, Bortezomib is also an immunosuppressant, and one of its known side effects is an increased risk of reactivating latent infections, including herpes zoster (shingles). Herpes zoster is caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, which remains dormant in nerve tissue after an initial chickenpox infection. Immunosuppressive therapies can lower the body's immune response, allowing this virus to reactivate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lenalidomide: While lenalidomide is also used in the treatment of multiple myeloma and has immunomodulatory effects, it is less commonly associated with herpes zoster reactivation compared to Bortezomib.

 

Option C. Daratumumab: This monoclonal antibody targets CD38 on myeloma cells and has a different side effect profile, with a lower risk of herpes zoster reactivation.

 

Option D. Melphalan: Melphalan is an alkylating agent used in the treatment of multiple myeloma, but it is less likely than Bortezomib to cause reactivation of herpes zoster.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bortezomib, a proteasome inhibitor used in the treatment of multiple myeloma, is most likely associated with the reactivation of herpes zoster due to its immunosuppressive properties. This highlights the importance of monitoring patients on such treatments for signs of viral reactivation

questions.text: Which infection is typically associated with a creamy, fishy odor? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gardnerella

 

Bacterial Vaginosis (BV) caused by Gardnerella vaginalis produces a characteristic fishy odor vaginal discharge. This distinctive odor is one of the key diagnostic criteria for BV. The discharge is typically thin, homogeneous, gray-white that coats the vaginal walls. The fishy smell becomes more pronounced during the "Whiff test" when 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) is added to the discharge, releasing volatile amines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas: Trichomonas infection causes a greenish-yellowish discharge that is often frothy. It's associated with dysuria, dyspareunia, and the characteristic "strawberry cervix" appearance, but lacks the fishy odor.

 

Option C. Candida: Candida infection presents with thick curdy white discharge resembling cottage cheese or flakes adherent to the vaginal wall. It causes intense pruritus but has no fishy odor. The vaginal pH remains acidic (<4.5).

 

Option D. Chlamydia: Chlamydia typically causes mucopurulent cervical discharge but is not associated with fishy odor. It's often asymptomatic and is a common cause of cervicitis and PID when it ascends to the upper genital tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a fishy odor, especially when performing the Whiff test, is a pathognomonic feature of Bacterial Vaginosis, which provides a key clinical distinction from other vaginal infections.

questions.text: A 4-year-old patient presented with a rectal mass 2.5 cm by 3 cm. On biopsy it had the presence of colonic mucosa with multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells.  Which of the following is a likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hamartoma

 

The clinical history of a rectal mass on biopsy having the colonic mucosa with multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells is suggestive of a juvenile polyp. This polyp is an example of a hamartomatous polyp.     

 

Hamartoma:

 

  • Definition: A hamartoma is a benign, focal malformation that resembles a neoplasm but grows at the same rate as the surrounding tissues. It is composed of an abnormal mixture of tissue elements that are normally found at that site.
  • Juvenile Polyp: A type of hamartomatous polyp commonly found in children. It is characterized by the presence of dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells, as described in the biopsy findings.
  • Clinical Presentation: Typically presents as a solitary rectal polyp in young children, often causing painless rectal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Choristoma: A benign growth of normal tissue in an abnormal location, not consistent with the described biopsy findings.

 

Option C. Adenoma: A benign neoplasm of glandular tissue, typically presenting with dysplastic changes, not the dilated glands with mucin and inflammatory cells.

 

Option D. Adenocarcinoma: A malignant tumor of glandular origin, which would show invasive growth and cellular atypia, not consistent with the benign nature of the findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A rectal mass in a young child with biopsy findings of colonic mucosa and multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells is indicative of a juvenile polyp, which is a type of hamartomatous polyp.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came with diffuse, severely contaminated perforation peritonitis due to hollow viscus. He underwent laparotomy for it. On day 7 post-op, he developed signs of wound infection and subsequently, the wound showed dehiscence with exposure of underlying tissues as shown below. His vital signs are stable with no evidence of intra-abdominal sepsis. What is the appropriate management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vacuum assisted closure (VAC)

 

Explanation:

 

The patient underwent laparotomy for perforation peritonitis and developed wound infection followed by wound dehiscence on postoperative day 7. Given that:

 

  • The wound is open with exposed underlying tissues.
  • Vital signs are stable.
  • No evidence of intra-abdominal sepsis.

 

This suggests a "burst abdomen" or post-op wound dehiscence, which is best managed using Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC therapy).

 

  • Promotes granulation tissue formation and wound healing.
  • Reduces bacterial load and infection risk.
  • Decreases edema and maintains a moist environment.
  • Prepares the wound for secondary closure or grafting if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suturing of Wound → Incorrect

 

  • Primary closure is not recommended because the wound is infected and dehiscent.
  • Attempting suturing would increase the risk of abscess formation and wound breakdown.

 

Option C. Normal Saline-Soaked Gauze → Partially Correct but Not Ideal

 

  • Saline dressings can be used but do not actively promote wound healing as well as VAC therapy.
  • More suitable for minor dehiscence, not large wounds with exposed tissue.

 

Option D. None of the Above → Incorrect

 

  • The patient requires wound management to prevent secondary infections and facilitate healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) therapy is the best treatment for wound dehiscence after laparotomy, as it promotes granulation tissue formation, reduces infection risk, and optimizes healing.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is an inhibitor of ATP binding cassette efflux pumps? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Verapamil

 

Verapamil is known to inhibit the activity of ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporters, such as P-glycoprotein, which is one of the most well-studied drug efflux transporters. By inhibiting P-glycoprotein, verapamil can increase the intracellular concentration of various drugs, which is why it is sometimes used as a pharmacokinetic enhancer to improve drug absorption and decrease drug clearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tacrolimus: Tacrolimus is an immunosuppressant drug used mainly after allogeneic organ transplant to reduce the activity of the patient's immune system and lower the risk of organ rejection. It is not an inhibitor of the ATP-binding cassette efflux transporters.

 

Option B. Nifedipine: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker used primarily to treat hypertension and angina pectoris. It is not known to inhibit ABC efflux transporters.

 

Option C. Diltiazem: Diltiazem, like verapamil, is a calcium channel blocker, but it is not as potent as verapamil in inhibiting P-glycoprotein. However, it does have some effect on drug efflux transporters, but to a lesser extent compared to verapamil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Verapamil is a known inhibitor of ATP-binding cassette transporters, particularly P-glycoprotein, and can be used to enhance the pharmacokinetics of various drugs by increasing their intracellular concentrations.

choices.text: Decreased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings
Decreased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction

questions.text: Myasthenia gravis is associated with: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Decreased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction

 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder where antibodies target and destroy acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. This impairs the ability of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine to stimulate muscle contractions, leading to decreased synaptic transmission. The disease is characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue, particularly worsening with activity and improving with rest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased myosin: This option is not related to myasthenia gravis, which primarily affects the neurotransmitter receptors, not the muscle fiber proteins like myosin.

 

Option B. Decreased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings: While decreased acetylcholine release can affect neuromuscular function, in myasthenia gravis, the principal issue is the reduced effectiveness of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction due to antibody-mediated receptor damage, not a reduction in its release. Occurs with pre-synaptic blockers like bungarotoxin of krait causing reduced release of Ach rendering neostigmine ineffective.

 

Option C. Absence of troponin C: This is unrelated to the pathophysiology of myasthenia gravis. Troponin C is involved in the regulation of muscle contraction in skeletal and cardiac muscle, not neurotransmitter release or receptor function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is an autoimmune disease characterized by Ab to postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors. Hence, treated with steroids and immunomodulators.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presenting with recurrent respiratory infections. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CPAM


Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM) is a congenital lung lesion characterized by multiple cystic spaces within the lungs, often detected through imaging such as CT or X-rays. In this case, the child’s imaging shows a multi-cystic, bubbly appearance with air-filled spaces, which is typical of CPAM. CPAM often presents with recurrent respiratory infections due to the abnormal lung structure. Although the images combine antenatal ultrasound and postnatal imaging, they highlight the congenital nature of the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyopneumothorax: This condition involves pus and air within the pleural cavity, usually caused by infection or trauma. It presents with an air-fluid level, often with signs of pleural infection such as fever and chest pain. The multi-cystic appearance seen in the imaging does not match this condition.

 

Option C. CDH (Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia): CDH involves the herniation of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity, usually on the left side. CDH presents with bowel loops in the chest and displacement of the lung tissue, which is not observed here. The appearance of the lesion on the right side with multiple air-filled cysts rules out CDH.

 

Option D. Lung abscess: A lung abscess is a localized area of necrosis and pus within the lung, often appearing as a round lesion with an air-fluid level. This differs significantly from the bubbly, multi-cystic appearance seen in the imaging, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:


CPAM is characterized by multiple cystic, air-filled spaces in the lung and is a congenital lesion that often presents with recurrent respiratory infections.

questions.text: Alpha 1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elastase

 

Alpha 1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme neutrophil elastase.

 

On serum electrophoresis, alpha-1-antitrypsin (-1-AT), also known as alpha 1-protease inhibitor, is a glycoprotein that typically makes up the alpha1-globulin fraction of the plasma proteins.

 

It is typically produced in the liver and found in macrophages, circulating blood, and tissue fluids.

 

The name "Alpha1-protease inhibitor" comes from the fact that alpha1AT's primary role in the body is to inhibit proteases. The proteases, particularly the elastases, come from neutrophils.

 

The anti-elastase activity of alpha1-AT prevents neutrophil elastase from digesting lung parenchyma, despite its ability to do so.

 

In the proteinase inhibitor (Pi) locus on chromosome 14, co-dominantly expressed genes that code for 1-antitrypsin are located. The Pi locus has a wide variety of alleles and is highly polymorphic.

 

Those who have the alpha1-AT deficit develop panacinar pulmonary emphysema.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase: Not primarily inhibited by A1AT; it is an antioxidant enzyme.

 

Option B. Collagenase: Also not a primary target of A1AT; these enzymes break down collagen in connective tissue.

 

Option D. Phospholipase: Not inhibited by A1AT; involved in the hydrolysis of phospholipids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha 1-antitrypsin's critical role is to inhibit neutrophil elastase, thus protecting connective tissue from inflammatory damage, particularly in the lungs and liver.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with gum bleeding and fever for the past 2 months. General examination showed pallor and the systemic examination was unremarkable. Laboratory examination revealed Hb level- 3 gm/dI, TLC-1500/microL, platelet count - 15000/microL. Peripheral smear shows macrocytes and the reticulocyte count is 0.5. Bone marrow examination revealed fatty streaks and absent megakaryocytes but no immature cells. What is the likely diagnosis? (Hb- Hemoglobin, TLC- Total leucocyte count)? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia

 

The given clinical scenario showing a young male with gum bleeding, fever, pancytopenia, and a low reticulocyte count with bone marrow showing fatty streaks and no immature cells is suggestive of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia.

 

Key Diagnostic Features of Aplastic Anemia:

 

  • Pancytopenia (low Hb, WBC, and platelets)
  • Hypocellular (fatty) bone marrow
  • No immature/blast cells
  • Low reticulocyte count (indicates bone marrow failure)
  • Macrocytes due to ineffective hematopoiesis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH is characterized by hemolysis, hemoglobinuria (especially in the morning), and thrombosis. The presentation of pancytopenia with bone marrow aplasia is more suggestive of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia.

 

Option C. Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS): MDS are a diverse group of hematopoietic clonal stem cell disorders characterized by abnormal development of various marrow elements (i.e., dysmyelopoiesis), cytopenias, cellular marrow, and ineffective blood cell formation.

 

Option D. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis can cause pancytopenia if the bone marrow is involved, but the bone marrow would show granulomas rather than the fatty streaks and absence of immature cells seen in aplastic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of pancytopenia

 

I. Aplastic anemia

 

II. Pancytopenia with normal or increased marrow cellularity

 

e.g.

 

  1.  Myelodysplastic syndromes
  2. Hypersplenism
  3.  Megaloblastic anemia

 

III. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria

 

IV. Bone marrow infiltrations

 

e.g:

 

  1. Hematologic malignancies (leukemias, lymphomas, myeloma)
  2. Non-hematologic metastatic malignancies
  3. Storage diseases
  4. Osteopetrosis
  5. Myelofibrosis

questions.text: Which brain region's lesion leads to prosopagnosia?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Occipito-temporal

 

Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize faces, which results from lesions in the occipito-temporal cortex, specifically the fusiform face area. This region is specialized for facial recognition and processing. The right hemisphere's fusiform gyrus is particularly critical for this function. When damaged, patients can still see faces normally but cannot identify them as familiar - they may even fail to recognize their own face in a mirror, despite having intact visual perception of other objects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parietal lobe - Lesions here typically cause deficits like hemineglect (right parietal), Gerstmann syndrome (left angular gyrus with agraphia, acalculia, finger agnosia, right-left confusion), or constructional/dressing apraxia, not prosopagnosia.

 

Option B. Frontal lobe - Damage causes executive dysfunction, personality changes, motor deficits, and Broca's aphasia when in the dominant hemisphere. Face recognition remains intact.

 

Option D. Parieto-occipital - While this region is involved in complex visual processing, lesions here typically cause visual spatial deficits like Balint's syndrome rather than specific face recognition problems.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Prosopagnosia results from damage to specialized face-processing regions in the occipito-temporal cortex (fusiform face area), typically following right posterior cerebral artery territory infarcts.

choices.text: MTP can be done routinely after 24 weeks POG
MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case
MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case only if it threatens the life of the mother
MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case with 1 Doctor’s opinion only

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented to your hospital emergency with pregnancy 22 weeks, which was a result of rape. Correct statement regarding Medical Termination of Pregnancy is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case

 

According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act of India, MTP is permitted up to 24 weeks of pregnancy. For gestation periods from 0 to 20 weeks, it is considered low risk and only one doctor’s opinion is required.

 

However, for gestation periods from 20 to 24 weeks, it is categorized as high risk, and the approval of two doctors is required. This high-risk category includes specific situations such as rape, incest, disability, and when the woman is a minor. Since the woman in the question is 22 weeks pregnant due to rape, MTP is permissible under these regulations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MTP can be done routinely after 24 weeks POG: This is incorrect because MTP after 24 weeks is not routinely allowed. It requires a medical board's approval and is only permitted in exceptional cases involving severe fetal anomalies or conditions that endanger the mother’s life.

 

Option C. MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case only if it threatens the life of the mother: This statement is incorrect. For 20-24 weeks POG, MTP is permitted not only for life-threatening conditions but also for cases involving rape, incest, disability, and minors.

 

Option D. MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case with 1 Doctor’s opinion only: This is incorrect because two doctors' opinions are required for high-risk cases between 20-24 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MTP between 20-24 weeks of pregnancy is considered high risk and requires two doctors' opinions, especially in cases of rape, incest, disability, or if the woman is a minor.

choices.text: Volume that remains in lungs after forced expiration

questions.text: Which of the following represents functional residual capacity? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Expiratory reserve volume + residual volume

 

Explanation

 

The functional residual capacity equals the expiratory reserve volume(1000-1100ml) + residual volume(1100-1200ml). This is the amount of air that remains in the lungs at the end of normal expiration (about 2300 milliliters).

 

Vital capacity - Total volume of air that can be forcefully expired after forceful inspiration


            = Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume + Expiratory reserve volume
 

 

Expiratory capacity – tidal volume + ERV

 

Residual volume (1100-1200) - Volume that remains after forced expiration

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Volume expired after normal inspiration: Incorrect as this description fits more closely with tidal volume, which is the normal volume of air displaced between normal inhalation and exhalation when extra effort is not applied.

 

Option B. Volume that remains in lungs after forced expiration: Incorrect as this specifically defines residual volume (RV), not the combination of ERV and RV.

 

Option D. Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume: Incorrect, this combination describes the inspiratory capacity, which is the total volume of air that can be exhaled after a maximal inhalation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the sum of the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) and the Residual Volume (RV). It represents the volume of air remaining in the lungs at the end of a normal exhalation, ensuring continuous gas exchange between breaths.

questions.text: A first year MBBS student presented to OPD with intermittent episodes of impending doom accompanied by profuse sweating. The episodes usually occur before her exams. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Panic disorder

 

The symptoms described are indicative of panic attacks, which are sudden periods of intense fear or discomfort that may include palpitations, sweating, trembling or shaking, and feelings of impending doom. These attacks can occur unexpectedly or in anticipation of a specific trigger, such as before an exam.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conversion disorder is characterized by neurological symptoms not explained by a neurological disease or other medical condition.

 

Option C. Social anxiety disorder is characterized by an intense fear of social situations.

 

Option D. Generalized anxiety disorder involves excessive anxiety and worry about multiple events or activities most days for at least 6 months, not limited to performance situations like exams.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of panic attack. Panic attack is a sudden, intense episode of fear or discomfort often accompanied by a sensation of impending doom. The symptoms during panic attack usually involve sudden onset of palpitations, chest pain, choking sensations, dizziness and feeling of unreality (depersonalization or derealization).Along with these physical symptoms there is also fear of dying, losing control or going mad.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 394.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a mode of transmission for Brucella? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Person to person

 

Explanation:


Person to person transmission of Brucella is extremely rare. This type of transmission can only occur in very specific circumstances such as through breast milk, tissue transplantation, or blood transfusions. However, these routes are epidemiologically insignificant when considering the overall spread of brucellosis. Human-to-human transmission is not considered a meaningful route of infection in public health assessments of this disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Through the placenta of animals - This is a common mode of transmission within animal populations. Brucellosis frequently spreads through transplacental transmission in domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats, allowing the disease to maintain itself within herds.

Option B. Aerosol transmission - This is a significant mode of transmission, particularly in occupational settings. Inhalation of infectious aerosols can occur in environments such as slaughterhouses, animal pens, or laboratories handling the organism. This represents an important occupational hazard for veterinarians, farmers, and laboratory workers.

 

Option D. Consuming uncooked food - This is one of the primary routes of human infection. Consumption of unpasteurized dairy products (milk, cheese) or undercooked meat from infected animals commonly leads to brucellosis. This is why pasteurization of milk products is so important in controlling this disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Brucellosis is primarily a zoonotic disease with transmission occurring through direct animal contact, consumption of contaminated animal products, or inhalation of aerosols, while person-to-person transmission is negligible in the epidemiology of this infection.

questions.text: The most common cause of Central Pontine Myelinolysis (CPM) is the rapid correction of? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyponatremia.

 

Explanation:

 

Central pontine myelinolysis (CPM), also known as osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS), is most commonly caused by rapid correction of hyponatremia. Overly rapid correction of hyponatremia (>8–10 mM in 24 h or 18 mM in 48 h) disrupts the integrity of the blood-brain barrier, allowing immune mediators to enter and contribute to demyelination. The lesions of ODS classically affect the pons, where the delay in reaccumulation of osmotic osmolytes is particularly pronounced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypokalemia: While hypokalemia can cause various neurological symptoms including weakness and paralysis, it is not the primary cause of CPM. Neurological manifestations of hypokalemia differ from the characteristic demyelinating pattern seen in CPM.

 

Option B. Hypomagnesemia: Hypomagnesemia can exacerbate hyponatremia and potentiate hypokalemia, but it is not directly implicated as a cause of CPM. Magnesium disorders have distinct neurological manifestations.

 

Option D. Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcemia causes neuromuscular irritability, tetany, and seizures, but is not associated with the development of demyelinating lesions in the pons characteristic of CPM.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Central pontine myelinolysis occurs when chronic hyponatremia is corrected too rapidly, causing asymmetric reaccumulation of brain osmolytes and subsequent demyelination, particularly affecting the pons. The safest correction rate for chronic hyponatremia is less than 8-10 mEq/L in 24 hours or 18 mEq/L in 48 hours.

choices.text: Variation in cell size and shape
Replacement of one type of cell by other

questions.text: Anaplasia refers to: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lack of differentiation

 

A lack of differentiation is referred to as anaplasia.

 

Anaplasia means "backward formation," implying a reversal of differentiation to a more primitive level.

 

As a result of anaplasia, morphological and functional changes in the neoplastic cells are observed like:

 

  • Loss of polarity
  • Pleomorphism - variation in the size and shape of cells
  • Increased N: C ratio (nucleus: cytoplasmic ratio) - around 1:5 in normal cells, increases to 1:1 in malignant cells
  • Hyperchromasia - coarsely clumped and darkly stained chromatin within irregular nuclei
  • Nucleolar changes - prominent nucleolus or nucleoli in the nucleus reflecting increased nucleoprotein synthesis
  • Increased mitosis - atypical, bizarre mitotic figures
  • Tumour giant cells
  • Functional (Cytoplasmic) changes

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Variation in cell size and shape: This is a feature of pleomorphism, a characteristic of anaplasia but not the definition of it.

 

Option C. Replacement of one type of cell by another: This describes metaplasia.

 

Option D. Disordered arrangement of tumor cells: This can be a feature seen in anaplastic tumors but is not definitive for anaplasia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaplasia indicates a high grade of malignancy due to the significant loss of differentiation and structural and functional changes in the neoplastic cells.

choices.text: Previous manual removal of placenta

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered as a factor for a high-risk pregnancy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Previous manual removal of placenta

 

Explanation:

 

Previous manual removal of the placenta does not automatically categorize a subsequent pregnancy as high-risk. High-risk pregnancies are characterized by various factors that may complicate the pregnancy or pose risks to the mother and fetus. These factors include existing health conditions, certain lifestyle factors, age-related risks, and specific pregnancy conditions.

 

High-risk pregnancy factors according to the NIH include:

 

  1. Existing health conditions:
    • Hypertension
    • Diabetes
    • Autoimmune diseases
    • PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome)
    • Thyroid disorders
    • Obesity
    • HIV
    • Anemia
    • Uterine fibroids
  2. Age:
    • Adolescence
    • First-time pregnancy at age >35 years
  3. Lifestyle factors:
    • Alcohol consumption
    • Smoking
    • Drug use
  4. Pregnancy conditions:
    • Multiple pregnancy
    • Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM)
    • Pre-eclampsia
    • Previous preterm birth
    • Congenital or chromosomal anomalies
    • Polyhydramnios or oligohydramnios
    • Rh iso-immunization
    • Antepartum hemorrhage
    • Fetal growth restriction

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obesity: Obesity is a significant factor for a high-risk pregnancy as it is associated with various complications such as gestational diabetes, pre-eclampsia, and increased risk of cesarean delivery.

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: Polyhydramnios, which is an excessive amount of amniotic fluid, can lead to complications such as preterm labor and fetal malformations, making it a high-risk condition.

 

Option C. Anemia: Anemia during pregnancy can affect the health of both the mother and the fetus, leading to conditions such as preterm birth and low birth weight, thus categorizing it as high-risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Previous manual removal of the placenta is not considered a factor for categorizing a subsequent pregnancy as high-risk.

 

Ref: https://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/high-risk

questions.text: A child presents with sudden loss of vision in one eye, pain on eye movement and there was RAPD. This is due to the lesion of:(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Optic nerve

 

The symptoms described are indicative of an issue at the level of the optic nerve, such as optic neuritis, which can cause sudden vision loss, pain on movement of the eye, and RAPD.

 

The optic nerve transmits visual information from the eye to the brain. A lesion in the optic nerve can cause sudden vision loss in one eye, pain with eye movement (often associated with optic neuritis), and an RAPD, where the pupil of the affected eye does not respond as well to light as the unaffected eye due to the reduced sensory input from the retina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic Chiasma: The optic chiasma is the part of the brain where the optic nerves partially cross. Lesions at this location typically produce visual field defects in both eyes, such as bitemporal hemianopia, where both outer (temporal) halves of the visual field are lost. It would not typically cause sudden vision loss in one eye, nor would it be associated with pain on eye movement.

 

Option B. Optic Tract: The optic tract carries visual information from the optic chiasma to the lateral geniculate nucleus and other areas. Lesions here can result in homonymous hemianopia, where the same visual field cut is observed in both eyes. Like with optic chiasma lesions, optic tract issues do not typically cause sudden unilateral vision loss or pain on eye movement.

 

Option C. Visual Cortex: The visual cortex is located in the back of the brain and is responsible for processing visual information. Damage to the visual cortex can cause a variety of complex visual disturbances, including homonymous hemianopia or cortical blindness, depending on the extent and location of the damage. However, it would not cause unilateral vision loss, pain on eye movement, nor an RAPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presentation of sudden vision loss in one eye, pain on eye movement, and RAPD suggests a lesion in the optic nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is not typically used in the management of chronic hypocalcemia? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Etidronate.

 

Etidronate, a bisphosphonate, is not used in treating chronic hypocalcemia. Bisphosphonates are primarily antiresorptive agents that inhibit osteoclast activity and are indicated for conditions like osteoporosis, Paget's disease, and hypercalcemia. In fact, bisphosphonates can worsen hypocalcemia by reducing bone resorption and calcium release from bone, which is counterproductive in chronic hypocalcemic states.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiazides: This is incorrect because thiazides are actually used in chronic hypocalcemia management. Thiazides reduce urinary calcium excretion (↓Uca) and help increase serum calcium levels (↑S.ca), making them beneficial in hypocalcemic states.

 

Option C. Elemental calcium: This is incorrect because calcium supplementation is the cornerstone of managing chronic hypocalcemia. Oral calcium (carbonate or citrate) is a fundamental component in the treatment regimen for patients with persistent hypocalcemia.

 

Option D. Vitamin D analogs: This is incorrect because vitamin D analogs, particularly calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D), are essential in hypocalcemia management. Calcitriol enhances intestinal calcium absorption and is typically administered alongside calcium supplements.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The management of chronic hypocalcemia centers on calcium replacement (oral calcium), optimization of intestinal calcium absorption (vitamin D analogs/calcitriol), and reduction of urinary calcium excretion (thiazides), while bisphosphonates are contraindicated as they can worsen hypocalcemia.

questions.text: Vaccine kept at the lowest level inside an Ice lined refrigerator (ILR) at PHC: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) OPV

 

In an Ice Lined Refrigerator (ILR), which is commonly used at Primary Health Centers (PHCs) to store vaccines, the temperature varies from 2°C at the bottom to 8°C at the top. Vaccines that require colder temperatures, closer to 2°C, are stored at the lowest level of the refrigerator because cold air settles down.

 

OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine): OPV is stored at the lowest level of the ILR because it requires a colder environment. It can even tolerate freezing temperatures and can be stored in a deep freezer at -15°C to -25°C, making it suitable for the coldest section of the refrigerator.

 

  • Lyophilized vaccines like BCG, measles, and rotaviral vaccine are also stored at lower levels since they need a stable and colder temperature.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BCG: While BCG is a lyophilized vaccine and is stored at a lower level, it is not specifically the answer for this question as OPV is more specifically associated with the lowest level due to its freezing tolerance.

 

Option C. DPT: DPT vaccine is stored at the upper levels of the ILR where temperatures are closer to 6-8°C. This vaccine does not require the colder conditions found at the bottom of the refrigerator.

 

Option D. Rotaviral vaccine: Similar to BCG, the rotaviral vaccine is a lyophilized vaccine stored lower in the ILR, but OPV is the more critical vaccine stored at the lowest level due to its requirement for cold and even freezing conditions.

 

Educational Objective:


OPV is stored at the lowest level of the ILR due to its requirement for the coldest storage conditions, ranging from 2°C and even tolerating freezing conditions, ensuring vaccine potency and effectiveness.

choices.text: Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound

questions.text: The best method to obtain tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound

 

Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is a minimally invasive technique that involves the insertion of a needle through the stomach wall under ultrasound guidance to obtain a sample of pancreatic tissue. EUS-guided biopsy has a high diagnostic accuracy and is considered the preferred method for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma as it avoids the spillage of tumor cells into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI-guided biopsy: Is a technique that uses magnetic resonance imaging to guide the insertion of a needle to obtain a tissue sample. This technique is not commonly used for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to its low accuracy.

 

Option C. Laparoscopic-guided biopsy: Is a minimally invasive surgical technique that involves the insertion of a laparoscope through small incisions in the abdomen to visualize the pancreas and obtain a tissue sample. Laparoscopic biopsy is a more invasive option than EUS-guided biopsy but may be used when other methods are unsuccessful.

 

Option D. Percutaneous transperitoneal biopsy: Involves the insertion of a needle through the abdominal wall to obtain a tissue sample from the pancreas. This technique is less commonly used for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to the risk of complications such as bleeding and infection.

 

Overall, EUS-guided biopsy is the preferred method for obtaining tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma due to its high diagnostic accuracy and minimally invasive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is the preferred method for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to its high diagnostic accuracy and minimally invasive nature.

questions.text: All of the following are AIDS defining illnesses except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Oral Candidiasis

 

Oral candidiasis, while commonly associated with HIV infection, is not itself an AIDS-defining illness. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) list of AIDS-defining illnesses includes more severe manifestations such as candidiasis of the esophagus, trachea, bronchi, or lungs, but not oral candidiasis. This fungal infection is often seen in patients with HIV as a marker of immune suppression but does not qualify as an indicator of AIDS on its own.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Encephalopathy attributed to HIV: This is an AIDS-defining condition, as it represents a direct effect of HIV on the brain resulting in cognitive impairment and motor dysfunction.

 

Option B. Invasive cervical cancer: This is considered an AIDS-defining illness due to the high risk and prevalence of this cancer in individuals with advanced HIV, reflecting a significant degree of immunosuppression.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium tuberculosis of any site: Tuberculosis, whether pulmonary or extrapulmonary, is an AIDS-defining illness due to its severity and frequency in the context of HIV-induced immune suppression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Infectious Disease/Chap 202

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for the varicose vein. He now complains of sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Saphenous nerve

 

The given clinical scenario in a patient with sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot is suggestive of injury to the saphenous nerve. Injury to the saphenous nerve is common following varicose vein surgery.

 

Saphenous nerve is a branch of the femoral nerve.

 

Sensory Distribution: The saphenous nerve is the longest cutaneous nerve in the body and provides sensation to the anteromedial aspect of the leg down to the medial side of the foot.

 

Clinical Relevance: Injury to the saphenous nerve, particularly during varicose vein surgery given its proximity to the great saphenous vein, would result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sural nerve:  It is formed by the joining of branches from the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: It supplies sensation to the lateral and posterior aspect of the lower leg and the lateral side of the foot.
  • Clinical Relevance: Injury to the sural nerve would not result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option B. Superficial peroneal nerve:  Branch of the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: It provides sensation to the anterolateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum (top) of the foot, excluding the web space between the first and second toes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Damage to this nerve would cause sensory loss on the dorsum of the foot and the anterolateral aspect of the leg but not the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option C. Deep peroneal nerve: Another branch of the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Its sensory distribution is limited and includes the web space between the first and second toes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Injury to the deep peroneal nerve would affect the sensation between the first and second toes and would not result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Transverse septum in the proximal vagina
Complete vaginal atresia

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the OPD with a history of primary amenorrhea and cyclical pain. Perineal examination reveals a bulge protruding from the vagina. Identify the cause of this presentation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

 

Explanation:

 

  •  Primary amenorrhea with cyclical pain is suggestive of an obstructive cause.
  • O/e a bulge seen protruding from the vagina is suggestive of an imperforate hymen.
  • This classically presents as a bluish bulge distending the hymen.
  • The bulge (hematocolpos) is felt along the entire length of the vagina on doing a PR examination
  • Treatment: Cruciate incision and drainage of hamatocolpos is done.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Transverse septum in the proximal vagina: This also will present as primary amenorrhoea with cyclical abdominal pain as the menstrual blood accumulates inside. But on examination, the bulge wont be seen at the introitus as the obstruction is higher up in a proximal or high transverse vaginal septum.

 

Option B. Complete vaginal atresia: In Complete vaginal atresia, also the symptoms of primary amenorrhoea and cyclical abdominal pain will be present, but again the obstruction will be high. There will be hematometra. Local examination will reveal an absent vagina or a bling ending vagina.

 

Option D. Cervical agenesis: In cervical agenesis, again there will be hematometra, I.e. the obstruction is higher up and there will not ne any bulge seen on local exam.

 

Educational Objective

 

Primary amenorrhea with cyclical pain and a bulge protruding from the vagina is indicative of an imperforate hymen, requiring cruciate incision and drainage of hematocolpos.

 

Ref: Page no 450, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A 4-week-old infant presents with vomiting and constipation. On examination, a palpable abdominal mass is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHPS

 

Explanation:

 

Clinical features strongly suggest CHPS:

 

  • CHPS is caused by hypertrophy of the pyloric sphincter, leading to gastric outlet obstruction.
  • It typically presents in males, around 4-8 weeks of age.
  • Electrolyte abnormality: Hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to loss of gastric acid and dehydration.
  • Best initial test: Ultrasound abdomen → Shows a thickened pyloric muscle (> 4mm thick, > 16mm long).
  • Treatment: Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy (surgical incision of the hypertrophied pyloric muscle).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal atresia: Incorrect as it presents at birth with bilious vomiting and double-bubble sign on X-ray

 

 

Option B. Intussusception: Incorrect as it occurs in infants 6-18 months of age and presents with red currant jelly stools

 

 

Option D. Hirschsprung's disease: Incorrect as it presents at birth with failure to pass meconium within 48 hours and has delayed passage of stools

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CHPS classically presents at 4-8 weeks of age with non-bilious projectile vomiting and palpable olive-shaped mass in epigastrium.

 

Infantile Pyloric Stenosis (IHPS)

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage for molar pregnancy 6 months ago presents with persistent symptoms of abdominal pain and distention. On further evaluation, the beta- hCG levels were persistently elevated and cannonball foci were found on the chest X-ray. What is the appropriate management in this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methotrexate with folinic acid

 

Explanation:

 

Methotrexate with folinic acid: This is a clear case of post-molar choriocarcinoma with lung metastases. Treatment is based on prognostication and staging. According to the given scoring system, the parameters such as the time interval since the antecedent pregnancy, beta-hCG levels, and the presence of lung metastases suggest a low-risk choriocarcinoma. For low-risk choriocarcinoma, the recommended treatment is multi-dose single-agent chemotherapy with methotrexate. Methotrexate is administered in a multi-dose regimen (Day 1, 3, 5, 7) alternating with folinic acid (Day 2, 4, 6, 8).

 

 

  • < 6: LOW RISK
  • > 7 HIGH RISK

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Methotrexate alone might be considered for very low-risk cases. However, in this case, with persistent elevated beta-hCG levels and lung metastases, a multi-dose regimen along with folinic acid is preferred to enhance efficacy and reduce toxicity.

 

Option C. EMACO regimen: The EMACO regimen, which includes etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, and vincristine, is used for high-risk choriocarcinoma. This patient's score indicates a low-risk profile, making EMACO unnecessary and more toxic than needed.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is not the first line of treatment for choriocarcinoma, especially in the context of low-risk metastatic disease. It may be considered in cases of heavy bleeding or when the disease is confined to the uterus and chemotherapy is not effective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low-risk choriocarcinoma post-molar pregnancy with lung metastases is treated with a multi-dose regimen of methotrexate alternating with folinic acid

 

Ref: Page 789, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

choices.text: None of the above

questions.text: A patient presented with pus discharge from the urethra and dysuria. He had a history of unprotected sexual intercourse. Identify the following organism: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

    
The patient presents with symptoms of urethral discharge and dysuria, along with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse, which strongly suggests a sexually transmitted infection. The image provided shows Gram-negative diplococci, which are characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the bacterium responsible for gonorrhea. Neisseria gonorrhoeae typically causes symptoms like purulent discharge from the urethra, dysuria, and may be accompanied by other complications if untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. H. ducreyi: This bacterium causes chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful ulcers on the genitalia, not typically associated with pus discharge and dysuria as seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Candida: While Candida species can cause infections, they usually lead to candidiasis, presenting with symptoms like itching, discharge, and irritation but not the Gram-negative diplococci seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:


Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a Gram-negative diplococcus that causes gonorrhea, characterized by urethral discharge and dysuria, especially following unprotected sexual intercourse.

questions.text: A fetus with intrauterine growth restriction was born prematurely with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and diffuse petechiae at birth. A brain CT was done which revealed periventricular calcifications. What is the best method for the diagnosis of the etiological agent? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urine examination

 

Based on the clinical presentation, it appears that congenital cytomegalovirus infection is a likely diagnosis. The most effective method for diagnosing the specific cause of the infection is by examining urine samples. In order to diagnose congenital CMV infection, the best specimens to use for culture are urine and saliva, while the best specimens for PCR testing are saliva and cord blood.

 

Clinical features:

 

  1. Intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR)
  2. Prematurity
  3. Hepatosplenomegaly
  4. Jaundice
  5. Blueberry-muffin-like rash
  6. Thrombocytopenia, purpura
  7. Microcephaly,
  8. Intracranial calcifications
  9. Chorioretinitis
  10. Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)
  11. Mild increases in CSF protein.

 

Rx: Ganciclovir can limit hearing loss and improve the developmental outcome in symptomatically infected infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. liver biopsy: liver biopsy is the gold standard investigation of choice in Wilson disease.

 

Option C. Blood examination: Blood examination will not give us the diagnostic results.

 

Option D. CSF examination: CSF examination is useful in cases of meningitis or neonatal sepsis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urine examination is the preferred diagnostic method for identifying congenital cytomegalovirus infection, which typically presents with symptoms such as intrauterine growth restriction, prematurity, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, microcephaly, diffuse petechiae, and periventricular calcifications.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Selective Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitor that can be used for the treatment of ADHD? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reboxetine
