Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). Although Atomoxetine is the first-line SNRI approved for the treatment of ADHD, Reboxetine is the next best option available.

 

Reboxetine works by selectively inhibiting the reuptake of norepinephrine, thereby increasing its levels in the synaptic cleft. While Reboxetine is not commonly used for ADHD and is not specifically approved for this condition, it has been used off-label for the treatment of ADHD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methylphenidate: Methylphenidate is primarily a dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor. It is not selective for norepinephrine alone and is one of the most commonly prescribed medications for ADHD, but it does not fit the criteria of a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor.

 

Option C. Guanfacine: Guanfacine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, not a reuptake inhibitor. It is used in the treatment of ADHD, but its mechanism of action is different from that of a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor.

 

Option D. Modafinil: Modafinil is a stimulant-like drug used primarily for narcolepsy and other sleep disorders. It is not a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor and does not have a primary role in ADHD treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) that can be used off-label for the treatment of ADHD, although it is not the first-line treatment. Atomoxetine is the preferred NRI for ADHD, but in its absence, Reboxetine is the next best option among the given choices.

questions.text: What is the minimum number of antenatal care (ANC) visits required according to the 2010 Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MOHFW) guidelines? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans.  (d) 4

 

  • The minimum number of antenatal visits recommended is 4 visits covering the entire period of pregnancy. 
  • These visits follow a specific schedule: 1st visit within 12 weeks for registration and first check-up, 2nd visit between 14-26 weeks, 3rd visit between 28-34 weeks, and 4th visit between 36 weeks and term.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: One antenatal visit is grossly inadequate for monitoring pregnancy and detecting complications. A single visit cannot provide the necessary surveillance throughout the different stages of pregnancy.

 

Option B. 2: Two visits fall short of the recommended minimum and would not allow adequate monitoring of all stages of pregnancy, particularly in the critical third trimester.

 

Option C. 3: Three visits, while better than fewer, still does not meet the minimum requirement of 4 visits needed for comprehensive antenatal care.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A minimum of 4 antenatal visits is essential for adequate maternal and fetal monitoring throughout pregnancy, with each visit scheduled at specific gestational ages to detect and manage potential complications early.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe back ache and the following x-ray after an RTA. Diagnose the fracture present. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Chance fracture

 

The image presented shows a spine injury, and based on the clinical scenario (a patient presenting after an RTA or road traffic accident), the fracture pattern described fits that of a Chance fracture. A Chance fracture, also known as a flexion-distraction injury or seatbelt fracture, typically occurs due to high-force flexion injuries, such as in a car accident where a seatbelt restrains the lower body while the upper body moves forward. This type of fracture involves a horizontal break extending through all three spinal columns (anterior, middle, and posterior)

 

The Chance fracture goes from anterior to posterior, involving all three columns, which is a hallmark feature of this injury. The description matches the flexion-distraction mechanism associated with this fracture.

 

Additional Information

 

Common spine fractures:

 

  1. Jefferson fracture:
    • Also called a ring fracture of the atlas (C1 vertebra).
    • Mnemonic: JAT.
  2. Hangman's fracture:
    • Fracture through the interarticularis of the C2 vertebra, causing a slip of C2 over C3 (spondylolisthesis).
    • Mnemonic: H2 (Hangman’s fracture, C2 vertebra).
  3. Whiplash injury:
    • Occurs due to hyperextension followed by flexion (e.g., in a high-speed vehicle accident where the vehicle suddenly stops).
    • Resembles the motion of a whiplash.
  4. Wedge fracture:
    • The anterior height of the vertebral body is lowered while the posterior height remains normal.
  5. Burst fracture:
    • Involves damage to the anterior, middle, and posterior columns of the vertebra.
    • The vertebral body is damaged, involving both the anterior and middle columns.
    • Atlas (Jefferson) fracture is also considered a burst fracture.
  6. Chance Fracture:
    • The force moves from anterior to posterior, going all the way to the spinous process.
    • Involves flexion of the body with a distraction force.
    • Also known as jackknife or seatbelt fracture.
  7. Hinge fracture: A fracture where the skull base is divided into two halves: anterior and posterior.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burst fracture: A burst fracture involves damage to the anterior and middle columns of the vertebra, with fragments spreading outwards. While a burst fracture may result from high-energy trauma, the image and clinical description provided in this question are more characteristic of a Chance fracture. The distribution of injury in a burst fracture does not typically extend through all three columns.

 

Option C. Compression fracture: Compression fractures generally affect the anterior part of the vertebra, causing a wedge-shaped deformity, but they do not involve the middle and posterior columns like the Chance fracture. These fractures are often seen in patients with osteoporosis rather than as a result of high-energy trauma.

 

Option D. Fracture of spinous process: A fracture of the spinous process (such as a Clay-shoveler's fracture) usually involves a break in the posterior part of the vertebra only and does not involve the anterior or middle columns. This type of fracture typically occurs from direct trauma or forceful flexion but doesn't match the findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Chance fracture is a flexion-distraction injury that extends through all three columns of the spine and is commonly seen in patients who experience a sudden forward motion, such as in a seatbelt-related injury during a car accident.

questions.text: According to the berlin definition, moderate ARDS is characterized by all, except: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. PaO2/FiO2 ratio 200-300 mm/Hg

 

Option A:

 

The Berlin definition of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) classifies the severity based on the PaO2/FiO2 ratio assessed under specific conditions of oxygenation support. According to this definition, a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 200-300 mmHg characterizes mild ARDS, not moderate ARDS. Moderate ARDS is defined by a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 100-200 mm/Hg when assessed with at least 5 cm of water Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP).

 

Explanation:
 

Option B. Bilateral interstitial infiltrates: This is correct and consistent with all classifications of ARDS, which require bilateral opacities on imaging, either from chest radiographs or CT, indicative of pulmonary edema not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload.

 

Option C. Symptom onset within a week: True for the Berlin definition, which stipulates that ARDS must occur within 7 days of a known clinical insult or new or worsening respiratory symptoms.

 

Option D. No cardiac failure on echocardiography: Also true according to the Berlin definition, as the pulmonary edema should not be fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload, thus necessitating the exclusion of cardiac failure through echocardiography.

 

Educational Objective:

 

2012 Berlin Definition:

 

  1. Onset within 7 days after a known clinical insult or new or worsening respiratory symptoms
  2. B/L opacities (Alveolar/Interstitial that are "consistent with pulmonary edema" on chest radiographs or chest CT)
  3. Minimum PEEP setting or CPAP, 5 cm of water.

 

PaO2: FiO2 assessed on invasive mechanical ventilation (CPAP criterion used for the diagnosis of mild ARDS).

 

Categorization of ARDS severity (on the basis of FiO2):

 

  1. Mild: 200-300
  2. Moderate: 100-200
  3. Severe: <100

 

In resource limited settings Kigali Modifications was proposed (2016):

 

  1. Bilateral opacities could be documented by either ultrasonography or chest radiograph.
  2. Oxygenation criteria: pulse oximetry oxygen saturation (SpO2)/FiO2 ratio ≤ 315 without the requirement for PEEP.

 

Reference - Harrison/Respiratory Failure/Chap 301

questions.text: What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Becker's naevus

 

The given image shows Becker's naevus.

 

  • The condition in question is an epidermal melanocytic nevus, characterized by the clustering of melanocytes in the epidermis.
  • It is commonly hairy and tends to appear during adolescence when there is heightened sensitivity to androgens, especially in areas like the outer arms, scapular region, and chest.

 

A triad of features can be seen:

 

  1. Hypertrichosis
  2. Acne
  3. Brownish Hyperpigmentation

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Becker's naevus is a patchy, hyperpigmented lesion that often develops during adolescence and may include hypertrichosis, distinguishing it from congenital conditions such as Mongolian spots, Naevus of Ito, and congenital melanocytic naevi.

 

 

Reference: Bolognia 4th edition, chapter 112, page no 2232

Question Level – EASY 

Question Id-7443 Unique Key-Q6167342

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blastocyst

 

The image shows a blastocyst, which is a developmental stage formed on the 4th day of embryonic development. 

 

  • An outer cell mass (trophoblast) that appears as a single layer of cells forming the wall
  • An inner cell mass which will form the embryo proper
  • A fluid-filled cavity is clearly visible, which is characteristic of a blastocyst The blastocyst contains approximately 32 cells and is formed from the morula stage when fluid begins to accumulate between the cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morula: Incorrect because a morula is a solid ball of 16 cells without any cavity, formed on day 3 of development. The image clearly shows a cavity and cell differentiation.

 

Option C. Zygote: Incorrect because a zygote is a single cell formed by fusion of sperm and egg. The image shows multiple cells arranged in a specific pattern.

 

Option D. Gastrula: Incorrect because gastrula is a later stage of development after blastocyst, characterized by three germ layers. The image shows only two cell populations typical of a blastocyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The blastocyst is a key structure in early human development that forms around day 5 post-fertilization and is essential for implantation. It consists of a trophoblast and an inner cell mass, which give rise to the placenta and embryo, respectively.
